The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (threat vs. safe contrast) used to identify functional ROIs via cluster-wise tests (Z>2.3, cluster p<.05) and provides coordinates/tables and figures of activations for the healthy sample. Participants are within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are presented. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-only samples) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Differential neurobiological effects of expert advice on risky choice in adolescents and adults.
studies.abstract: We investigated behavioral and neurobiological mechanisms by which risk-averse advice, provided by an expert, affected risky decisions across three developmental groups [early adolescents (12-14 years), late adolescents (15-17 years), adults (18+ years)]. Using cumulative prospect theory, we modeled choice behavior during a risky-choice task. Results indicate that advice had a significantly greater impact on risky choice in both adolescent groups than in adults. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging, we investigated the neural correlates of this behavioral effect. Developmental effects on correlations between brain activity and valuation parameters were obtained in regions that can be classified into (i) cognitive control regions, such as dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and ventrolateral PFC; (ii) social cognition regions, such as posterior temporoparietal junction; and (iii) reward-related regions, such as ventromedial PFC (vmPFC) and ventral striatum. Within these regions, differential effects of advice on neural correlates of valuation were observed across development. Specifically, advice increased the correlation strength between brain activity and parameters reflective of safe choice options in adolescent DLPFC and decreased correlation strength between activity and parameters reflective of risky choice options in adult vmPFC. Taken together, results indicate that, across development, distinct brain systems involved in cognitive control and valuation mediate the risk-reducing effect of advice during decision making under risk via specific enhancements and reductions of the correlation strength between brain activity and valuation parameters.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social influence (expert advice) on decision-making, addressing social cognition processes. Includes an adult group (18+), meeting the 17–65 age criterion; participants appear healthy (no clinical populations reported). Directly relevant to social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (effects of expert/adult advice) during a decision-making task, explicitly probing social influence and social-cognition regions (e.g., TPJ, vmPFC, DLPFC). The sample includes a healthy adult group (ages 18–45) reported separately alongside adolescent groups. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (cluster-corrected maps with MNI coordinates and statistical tests) and presents adult-specific effects (e.g., vmPFC decreases in correlation with certainty equivalents in adults, t(23)=−2.28). Analyses are univariate task activation contrasts/parametric modulations rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Participants are healthy and within the 17–65 range. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: Higher or lower? The functional anatomy of perceived allocentric social hierarchies.
studies.abstract: The perception and judgement of social hierarchies forms an integral part of social cognition. Hierarchical judgements can be either self-referential or allocentric (pertaining to two or more external agents). In psychiatric conditions such as dissocial personality disorder and schizophrenia, the impact of hierarchies may be problematic. We sought to elucidate the brain regions involved in judging allocentric social hierarchies. Twenty-two healthy male subjects underwent three fMRI scans. During scanning, subjects answered questions concerning visually-presented target pairs of human individual's relative superiority within a specific social hierarchy or their perceived degree of social alliance (i.e., whether they were "friends or enemies"). Subjects also made judgements relating to target pairs' age, gender and fame to control for confounding factors and performed a baseline numerical task. Response times increased in line with hypothesized ascending executive load. Both social hierarchy and social alliance judgements activated left ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (VLPFC), left dorsal inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) and bilateral fusiform gyri. In addition, social alliance judgements activated right dorsal IFG and medial prefrontal cortex. When compared directly with social alliance, social hierarchy judgements activated left orbitofrontal cortex. Detecting the presence of social hierarchies and judging other's relative standing within them implicates the cognitive executive, in particular the VLPFC. Our finding informs accounts of 'normal' social cognition but our method also provides a means of probing the dissocial brain in personality disorder and schizophrenia where executive function may be dysfunctional.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used fMRI in 22 healthy adult (male) participants performing social-related tasks (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgments). Participants are within the adult age range; task assesses social cognition constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of allocentric social hierarchy/alliance judgements in healthy adults (22 right-handed male participants, mean age 24.2). It reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain univariate analyses (contrasts with p<0.05 FWE-corrected, tables of Talairach coordinates and SPM maps) for the healthy sample. The task is explicitly social (hierarchy/alliances). No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, results reported for healthy adults within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

studies.title: An fMRI study of violations of social expectations: when people are not who we expect them to be.
studies.abstract: The current study examines the effect of violations of social expectancies on the neural substrates of person perception. In an event-related fMRI experiment, participants were presented with the photographs of either Republican or Democrat politicians paired with either typical Republican or Democrat political views (e.g., "wants a smaller government" or "wants liberal supreme court judges"). Subjects were asked to form an impression of the targets using information about both their political affiliation and their political views. Of interest was the contrast between stereotypically congruent trials and stereotypically incongruent trials. The results reveal that brain regions previously involved in mentalizing (i.e., temporoparietal junction and medial prefrontal cortex) are preferentially recruited when viewing incongruent social targets.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI study of person perception/social expectations (social processing). Involves healthy adult participants (political targets) and reports neural results; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an original, task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 19–30) using a social cognition task (impression formation/expectancy violation about politicians). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts (incongruent > congruent) with random-effects analyses and FDR-corrected activations, and provides a table of coordinates and figures. Results are reported for the healthy sample separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. It therefore satisfies the fMRI social-processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting inclusion criteria, and does not violate exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and empirical original data).

studies.title: Brain mechanisms for processing affective touch.
studies.abstract: Despite the crucial role of touch in social development, there is very little functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) research on brain mechanisms underlying social touch processing. The "skin as a social organ" hypothesis is supported by the discovery of C-tactile (CT) nerves that are present in hairy skin and project to the insular cortex. CT-fibers respond specifically well to slow, gentle touch such as that which occurs during close social interactions. Given the social significance of such touch researchers have proposed that the CT-system represents an evolutionarily conserved mechanism important for normative social development. However, it is currently unknown whether brain regions other than the insula are involved in processing CT-targeted touch. In the current fMRI study, we sought to characterize the brain regions involved in the perception of CT-supported affective touch. Twenty-two healthy adults received manual brush strokes to either the arm or palm. A direct contrast of the blood-oxygenation-level-dependent (BOLD) response to gentle brushing of the arm and palm revealed the involvement of a network of brain regions, in addition to the posterior insula, during CT-targeted affective touch to the arm. This network included areas known to be involved in social perception and social cognition, including the right posterior superior temporal sulcus and the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC)/dorso anterior cingulate cortex (dACC). Connectivity analyses with an mPFC/dACC seed revealed coactivation with the left insula and amygdala during arm touch. These findings characterize a network of brain regions beyond the insula involved in coding CT-targeted affective touch.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=22) investigating perception of CT-targeted affective (social) touch, a social-processing task involving affiliation/social interaction; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of affective (social) touch in a sample of 22 healthy adults aged 19–35. The task targets social-affiliative touch (C-tactile/affective touch), which falls squarely under social-related processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (arm > baseline, palm > baseline, and arm > palm) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster corrections, and tables of peak coordinates and figures. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes whole-brain task activations, participants within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: External motivation to avoid prejudice alters neural responses to targets varying in race and status.
studies.abstract: Those who are high in external motivation to respond without prejudice (EMS) tend to focus on non-racial attributes when describing others. This fMRI study examined the neural processing of race and an alternative yet stereotypically relevant attribute (viz., socioeconomic status: SES) as a function of the perceiver's EMS. Sixty-one White participants privately formed impressions of Black and White faces ascribed with high or low SES. Analyses focused on regions supporting race- and status-based reward/salience (NAcc), evaluation (VMPFC) and threat/relevance (amygdala). Consistent with previous findings from the literature on status-based evaluation, we observed greater neural responses to high-status (vs low-status) targets in all regions of interest when participants were relatively low in EMS. In contrast, we observed the opposite pattern when participants were relatively high in EMS. Notably, all effects were independent of target race. In summary, White perceivers' race-related motivations similarly altered their neural responses to the SES of Black and White targets. Specifically, the findings suggest that EMS may attenuate the positive value and/or salience of high status in a mixed-race context. Findings are discussed in the context of the stereotypic relationship between race and SES.
keywords: external motivation to respond without prejudice
studies.abstract_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study (N=61 healthy adult White participants) performing a social impression-formation task of faces varying by race and socioeconomic status, examining neural responses (NAcc, VMPFC, amygdala). It investigates social perception/processing and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI study of social perception/evaluation (impression-formation of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status) relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=60 male, mean age 23.8), within 17–65 and reported separately. (3) The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results (exploratory whole-brain regressions and a reported VMPFC cluster for status effects, and whole-brain contrasts described in text/supplement), not limited to ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria apply (not only connectivity/rs-fMRI, not only between-group contrasts, empirical original fMRI data). Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Cerebral correlates and statistical criteria of cross-modal face and voice integration.
studies.abstract: Perception of faces and voices plays a prominent role in human social interaction, making multisensory integration of cross-modal speech a topic of great interest in cognitive neuroscience. How to define potential sites of multisensory integration using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is currently under debate, with three statistical criteria frequently used (e.g., super-additive, max and mean criteria). In the present fMRI study, 20 participants were scanned in a block design under three stimulus conditions: dynamic unimodal face, unimodal voice and bimodal face-voice. Using this single dataset, we examine all these statistical criteria in an attempt to define loci of face-voice integration. While the super-additive and mean criteria essentially revealed regions in which one of the unimodal responses was a deactivation, the max criterion appeared stringent and only highlighted the left hippocampus as a potential site of face- voice integration. Psychophysiological interaction analysis showed that connectivity between occipital and temporal cortices increased during bimodal compared to unimodal conditions. We concluded that, when investigating multisensory integration with fMRI, all these criteria should be used in conjunction with manipulation of stimulus signal-to-noise ratio and/or cross-modal congruency.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining perception and integration of faces and voices—a social perception/communication task—performed in human participants (n=20). Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit statement of clinical populations or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult participants and age range.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study (N=20) investigating cross-modal face and voice integration, a form of social perceptual processing (perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults (MeSH includes Young Adult) and analyses report group-level univariate whole-brain contrasts using standard statistical criteria (super-additive, max, mean) that identified loci such as hippocampus, occipital and temporal cortices. The paper also reports psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity but does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only results. Thus it meets the fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level univariate evidence inclusion criteria.

studies.title: How do we empathize with someone who is not like us? A functional magnetic resonance imaging study.
studies.abstract: Previous research on the neural underpinnings of empathy has been limited to affective situations experienced in a similar way by an observer and a target individual. In daily life we also interact with people whose responses to affective stimuli can be very different from our own. How do we understand the affective states of these individuals? We used functional magnetic resonance imaging to assess how participants empathize with the feelings of patients who reacted with no pain to surgical procedures but with pain to a soft touch. Empathy for pain of these patients activated the same areas (insula, medial/anterior cingulate cortex) as empathy for persons who responded to painful stimuli in the same way as the observer. Empathy in a situation that was aversive only for the observer but neutral for the patient recruited areas involved in self-other distinction (dorsomedial prefrontal cortex) and cognitive control (right inferior frontal cortex). In addition, effective connectivity between the latter and areas implicated in affective processing was enhanced. This suggests that inferring the affective state of someone who is not like us can rely upon the same neural structures as empathy for someone who is similar to us. When strong emotional response tendencies exist though, these tendencies have to be overcome by executive functions. Our results demonstrate that the fronto-cortical attention network is crucially involved in this process, corroborating that empathy is a flexible phenomenon which involves both automatic and controlled cognitive mechanisms. Our findings have important implications for the understanding and promotion of empathy, demonstrating that regulation of one's egocentric perspective is crucial for understanding others.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating empathy (perception/understanding of others), reporting neural activation during a social-related task in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages aren’t specified, the study clearly fits the review’s focus and likely used healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related fMRI study of empathy/social cognition in healthy adults (n=23, ages 19–34). The task is explicitly social (empathizing with similar vs. dissimilar others), fitting ‘‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’’ The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrasts (e.g., Pain > No Pain: Similar, Pain > No Pain: Dissimilar, No Pain: Dissimilar > Similar) with statistical thresholding and tables/figures of activations (coordinates and images). Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, the paper also provides univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, participants are within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

studies.title: From agents to objects: sexist attitudes and neural responses to sexualized targets.
studies.abstract: Agency attribution is a hallmark of mind perception; thus, diminished attributions of agency may disrupt social-cognition processes typically elicited by human targets. The current studies examine the effect of perceivers' sexist attitudes on associations of agency with, and neural responses to, images of sexualized and clothed men and women. In Study 1, male (but not female) participants with higher hostile sexism scores more quickly associated sexualized women with first-person action verbs ("handle") and clothed women with third-person action verbs ("handles") than the inverse, as compared to their less sexist peers. In Study 2, hostile sexism correlated negatively with activation of regions associated with mental state attribution-medial prefrontal cortex, posterior cingulate, temporal poles-but only when viewing sexualized women. Heterosexual men best recognized images of sexualized female bodies (but not faces), as compared with other targets' bodies; however, neither face nor body recognition was related to hostile sexism, suggesting that the fMRI findings are not explained by more or less attention to sexualized female targets. Diminished mental state attribution is not unique to targets that people prefer to avoid, as in dehumanization of stigmatized people. The current studies demonstrate that appetitive social targets may elicit a similar response depending on perceivers' attitudes toward them.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study 2 reports fMRI activation while participants viewed sexualized and clothed human targets, addressing mental state attribution (a social cognition task) in healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing/attribution of agency) in healthy adult participants. The sample comprises healthy heterosexual male adults (final n=21, age range within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (deviant-cell contrast: sexualized female vs other targets) with voxelwise thresholding (p<.001) and cluster correction (AlphaSim), tables/figures of activations, and correlations between hostile sexism and whole-brain activity—fulfilling the requirement for univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps. The task probes perception/understanding of others, matching the review’s social-related constructs. Although the sample is restricted to heterosexual male undergraduates (a demographic limitation), it nonetheless meets the inclusion criteria of healthy adult whole-brain fMRI task data, so the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Valuating other people's emotional face expression: a combined functional magnetic resonance imaging and electroencephalography study.
studies.abstract: Reading the facial expression of other people is a fundamental skill for social interaction. Human facial expressions of emotions are readily recognized but may also evoke the same experiential emotional state in the observer. We used event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging and multi-channel electroencephalography to determine in 14 right-handed healthy volunteers (29+/-6 years) which brain structures mediate the perception of such a shared experiential emotional state. Statistical parametric mapping showed that an area in the dorsal medial frontal cortex was specifically activated during the perception of emotions that reflected the seen happy and sad emotional face expressions. This area mapped to the pre-supplementary motor area which plays a central role in control of behavior. Low resolution brain electromagnetic tomography-based analysis of the encephalographic data revealed that the activation was detected 100 ms after face presentation onset lasting until 740 ms. Our observation substantiates recently emerging evidence suggesting that the subjective perception of an experiential emotional state-empathy-is mediated by the involvement of the dorsal medial frontal cortex.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Study used event-related fMRI (with EEG) while healthy adult participants (mean age 29) viewed and perceived others' emotional facial expressions—directly addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others/empathy). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study used event-related fMRI during a social task (perception of others’ emotional facial expressions) in healthy adult participants (n=14, mean age 29±6). The paper reports group-level statistical parametric mapping results identifying dorsal medial frontal cortex activation during emotion perception, indicating univariate, whole-brain task-evoked effects for the healthy/control group. It is not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

abstract_screening_results.reason: The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; although participants are within the age range and social variables were measured behaviorally, the imaging does not assess social processing during a task.

Functional MRI study of interactive joint-action (leader/follower) in skilled couple dancers — a social interaction task involving perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for full data extraction.
fMRI study using a social task (face evaluation varying race and socioeconomic status) in healthy adult participants (n=61); addresses perception/understanding of others and is not a review.

fMRI study with 16 healthy volunteers viewing and interpreting verbal and non-verbal social interactions, addressing social cognition/perception of others. Not a review; meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age not specified in abstract but likely adult; include for full-text verification.

Title and abstract indicate neural (anterior insula) mechanisms of oxytocin on approach behavior toward social stimuli, implying fMRI during a social task. However, the abstract does not explicitly state imaging modality or participant details (healthy adults, ages). Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI was collected while participants performed a mind-perception task (judging likelihood faces have internal states), which targets perception/understanding of others — a social-cognitive process. The study reports healthy adult participants and is an original fMRI study (not a review). Full text can confirm exact age range and sample details.

Study used fMRI in 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task—directly assessing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used while participants made social judgments (perceived intelligence and friendliness of faces), fitting social perception processing. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state they were healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI study where participants categorized prosodic expressions reflecting social communicative intentions (social communication). Human participants performed a social-related task; no exclusion criteria met. Abstract implies healthy adult sample; include for full-text review to confirm sample age and health details.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (male and female) performed a social interaction task involving others controlling vs free choices. The task probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others, social motivation), fitting the review’s fMRI social processing inclusion criteria.

Study used functional MRI during emotion perception tasks (facial, vocal, bimodal), which falls under social communication/perception of others. Abstract reports healthy human participants (no clinical groups indicated) and presents whole-brain and ROI fMRI results. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an original fMRI study comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal (in addition to an automated meta-analysis). This addresses social processing using fMRI and is not solely a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm demographics, but abstract provides sufficient basis to include.

Functional MRI study examining perception/understanding of social interactions in human participants (task contrasts interactive vs non-interactive and interaction types). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages not stated, participants are adults; include for full-text review.

This is a theoretical/review chapter discussing social-interactive neuroscience and development, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract does not report an fMRI experiment or healthy adult task-based data; it summarizes existing literature. It meets the exclusion criterion (review) and lacks necessary participant/method details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult males performing social-cognitive tasks (reflection on self and a friend), addressing perception/understanding of self and others. This directly meets the review objective and inclusion criteria; it is not a review or meta-analysis.

Study reports task-based fMRI including social processing in a large sample of healthy adults (Human Connectome Project, n=787). Tasks explicitly include social and emotion processing; participants are healthy adults within typical HCP age range (17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI in healthy adult women (ages 25–50) examining neural responses to erotic pictures/videos of other people, which pertains to perception/processing of social stimuli; abstract does not definitively state social-cognition framing, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Task involves dyadic joint action (leading/following/mutual) during fMRI and reports activation in social-cognitive, mentalizing, somatosensory, and reward areas. Participants are trained couple dancers (presumably healthy adults). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact ages if needed.

fMRI study in 36 healthy human subjects examining perception/understanding of others via observation of cooperative and affective social interactions. Task is social-related; not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text extraction.

fMRI was conducted during a communicative/collaborative retrieval task probing understanding of others (mentalizing), involving healthy human participants. This addresses social processing in healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Primary data fMRI studies comparing ATL responses to person-related and abstract social concepts; involves social-related processing (people, social terms). Not a review/meta-analysis. Likely conducted in healthy adult participants. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a social decision-making task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) probing Theory of Mind/social cognition (rTPJ activity). Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task in healthy adults) and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Task-based 7T fMRI (rest-task-rest) was used while healthy adult participants listened to attachment-related narratives, examining functional connectivity of social/attachment processing (social approach network). This directly meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study of social evaluation (in-group/out-group politicians) examining vACC during social processing; involves human participants performing a social task. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and directly addresses social-related processing; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

This is a resting-state fMRI study measuring spontaneous brain activity (fALFF). No fMRI data were acquired while participants performed a social-related task; behavioral/social measures (CFS, IAT, vignettes) were separate. Thus it does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing fMRI.

fMRI study where healthy participants judged social properties of biological motion (point-light displays and human-like walkers), directly addressing social perception/understanding. Abstract implies healthy adults but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and participant details.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to a social/moral dilemma involving kinship (perception and understanding of others). Involves healthy adult subjects (no disorders reported). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task. No exclusion criteria met.

Fits review objective (social processing fMRI in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis and no patient groups reported in abstract.

fMRI task assessed phonological short-term memory for letters and fingerspelling (sequence memory span), not social processes. Although fingerspelling is a communication modality, the task measured memory/visuomotor processing rather than social communication or other social-related constructs.

Abstract reports a single-case (n=1) fMRI study. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). A single subject does not meet the 'group' criterion, so exclude based on sample size.

Abstract reports an fMRI study comparing neural activation to romantic (affiliation/attachment) and sexual stimuli in monogamous vs non-monogamous adult men. It involves healthy participant groups and a social-related task, meeting inclusion criteria. Although exact ages/health not specified, participants are described as men (adults); insufficient ambiguous detail warrants inclusion for full-text review.

Direct fMRI experiments on mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition) matching the review objective. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI investigating social brain regions. Participant age/health not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract describes a narrative review on resting-state fMRI and social cognition rather than an original study reporting task-based fMRI data. It does not report human participants performing a social-related task (required inclusion) and appears to be a review article, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind (social cognition) processes in human participants; meets review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm eligibility. Include for full-text screening.

This paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis using probabilistic atlases to synthesize TPJ activations across studies, not an original fMRI study reporting new data from healthy participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Functional MRI study (N=34) investigating social-emotional processes (schadenfreude, fremdscham) and social cognition. Meets the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65) and meet eligibility.

fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others — clearly a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; no evidence of exclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI was conducted while participants played the Trust Game (a social reciprocity task). The sample comprised nineteen healthy adults. The study addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study examining integration of social information and reward during a group decision-making task; measures include fMRI, reaction time, and gaze. Task probes social influence/perception of others. Not a review. Although participant ages/health status are not specified in the abstract, the study likely used healthy adult subjects; if unclear, full-text review is warranted.

fMRI study examining neural activity during decisions to share news with other people, implicating self-related and perspective-taking regions (social cognition). Participants appear to be healthy adults; task involves social-related processing (sharing/considering others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social interaction task (making listeners laugh) examining self/other processing and ventral striatum, meeting the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

Functional MRI was used during an observe/imitate emotional faces task in healthy adult participants (final N=20), assessing emotion recognition and higher-level social inference (TASIT, RAD, Reading the Mind in the Eyes). This directly addresses social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (17 participants) where healthy adults performed mentalising/theory-of-mind tasks (social cognition). This directly addresses social processing in the brain and is not a review. Participant ages not specified but sample appears to be healthy adults, meeting inclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

fMRI study examining retrieval of biographical/person knowledge—clearly a social-processing task with fifty participants across two studies. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not specify ages (17–65). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages, health status, and task details.

Abstract addresses neural mechanisms of social information sharing and is relevant to social processing, but does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used or give participant details (age/health). Insufficient methodological detail—include for full-text review to determine fMRI use and participant eligibility.

fMRI study using dynamic face stimuli examining attention to emotional valence and age—clearly social perception of others. Abstract implies human participants (likely healthy adults) but does not state ages; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

This article is a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study with human participants; excluded per the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews or meta-analyses).

This paper is a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (30 articles). The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it should be excluded despite addressing social processing.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers (n=40) measuring brain response to emotional facial expressions (masked/unmasked), a social-related task (perception/understanding of others/affiliation). Participants are healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in human participants examining attribution of emotions to humans and animals — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study assessing neural responses to empathy for pain (social processing) in participants exposed to acute stress; reports neural activation and prosocial behavior in (presumably) healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults (N=38) performing mental state judgments about naturalistic social interactions, directly assessing social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Meets inclusion criteria; not a review.

fMRI study investigating mentalizing, empathy, and prosocial behavior — clear social-related task and neural measures. Abstract mentions neural correlates of face recognition but does not specify that an fMRI was used, the task details, or participant ages. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine whether fMRI social-task in healthy adults was used.

Article is a narrative review of neuroimaging studies (not original fMRI research). It is a review/meta-analytic-type paper focusing on development across ages rather than reporting fMRI data from healthy adults (17–65) performing social tasks; thus meets exclusion criteria for systematic reviews.

fMRI study examining neural responses during a socially competitive learning task (social interaction/social-referencing). Participants appear to be healthy adults; no clinical sample or review. Task is social-related and conducted during fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face emotional processing—a social perception task—meeting review topic. Abstract does not report participant characteristics (health status or ages 17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Not a review; include for full-text review to verify sample details.

Functional MRI was used while human (25 female) participants performed a social-cognition task about kin and friends, reporting BOLD activations in social brain regions. fMRI study where participants performed a prosocial learning task (choices yielding rewards for self, another person, or no one). This targets social processing (prosocial behavior/empathy) in human participants with no indication of clinical groups, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study reports task-based fMRI of emotion regulation (reappraisal) of angry faces—clearly a social-related processing task (perception/understanding of others). fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) in healthy adult participants examining neural responses related to social reward and understanding others; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract reports neural tracking in perigenual ACC and dorsomedial frontal area 9 during cooperative and competitive tasks, indicating fMRI was used during a social task (self–other perception). fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (N=25) viewed attachment-related vs. neutral scenes—a social/attachment task. Meets inclusion: social-related processing (attachment), functional MRI, and healthy adult sample. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Abstract reports functional MRI experiments during social tasks (Prisoner’s Dilemma and Ultimatum Game) manipulating sociality — directly relevant to social processing. fMRI study of self-reference vs reference to others—addresses social cognition (perception/understanding of self/others). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; per screening rules, include for full-text review when information is insufficient.

Task-based fMRI in adult participants (n=20) during observation of angry vs. joyful social interactions addresses perception/understanding of others (social processing). fMRI study with 34 human participants engaging in naturalistic viewing of social interactions; investigates social cognition (DMPFC response to others’ interactions). fMRI study examining neural correlates of social exclusion/performance evaluation (modified Cyberball), addressing social processing (dACC, AI, precuneus, TPJ, mPFC). Not a review; likely involves healthy adult participants. Include for full-text review.

fMRI study includes a social task (theory-of-mind/social attribution) and reports scanning subjects; not a review. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game (a social/economic exchange task) examining cooperative behavior and neural correlates of social attachment and emotion regulation; appears to involve healthy adult participants in a randomized longitudinal design. fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants performing a Theory of Mind task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining impression updating (perception/understanding of others), clearly a social-processing task. Abstract does not report participant demographics or health status; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

fMRI study where participants repeatedly inferred others' emotions (social perception/understanding of others), meeting the review’s task domain. Not a review/meta-analysis. fMRI study examining neural correlates of agentic self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations (social cognition/perception of self), in healthy adult sample implied; meets inclusion (task-based fMRI of social-related processing). Not a review.

fMRI study with a large sample of healthy adult participants (N=178) performing social-cognitive tasks (empathy and mentalizing). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract describes methods for analyzing overlapping brain network communities during rest and unspecified tasks; it does not mention any social-related tasks or social processing. Participants/tasks related to social constructs are not reported, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (empathy, perspective taking, attention) during a charitable giving task in human participants. Abstract examines neural correlates of mentalizing and effects of social experiences in adults, implying social cognition processing and neuroimaging. However it does not explicitly state task-based fMRI in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample meet criteria.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers performing a social interaction/aggression (retaliation) task — a social-processing paradigm (response to provocation). fMRI study in adults using a social-related task (socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation with a psychotherapist), assessing attachment/social functioning. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult sample but lacks explicit age range; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 38 participants performing a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) examining neural responses to social reward (ventral striatum). Participants appear to be healthy adults and the task is clearly social; meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (constructing and attending to the meaning of their own and others’ LEGO models) engaging social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ). fMRI study in healthy adults performing a social judgment task (evaluation of social dominance in faces), directly addressing social processing. Primary fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/processing of unexpected social vs non-social events (social cognitive task). Not a review/meta-analysis. fMRI experiment investigating person perception and mentalising (social cognition) in humans, not a review/meta-analysis. fMRI study using a trustworthiness ratings task (social cognition/perception of others). Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adults; insufficient info to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and ages.

Original fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=37) performing a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving videos). Investigates neural processing of social evaluation, fitting the review’s social-related processing objective. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Block-design fMRI study measuring neural responses to perception of facial expressions (social communication/perception of others). Involves healthy participants (not specified ages in abstract) and meets social-processing fMRI inclusion; include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy participants (n=20) examining social-related processing (emotional and cognitive empathy responses to feedback). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults. fMRI study of affective theory-of-mind (social cognition) with healthy participants (n=21 analyzed). Task clearly social-related (judging others’ emotions). Ages not reported in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm age range (17–65).

Primary research reporting fMRI data during guilt induction tasks that probe social cognition (affect and social-cognitive regions). Abstract describes rt-fMRI (simultaneous EEG-fMRI) used to train social communication and analyzes responses in right pSTS, i.e., a social-related fMRI task. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text is needed to confirm healthy adults. Include for full-text review.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI during live eye contact (a social interaction/perception task) and compares dyadic vs monadic conditions; this fits the review objective. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and details.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=26) performing a social learning task (judging others' generosity). Directly addresses social processing in humans; not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Primary research using functional MRI (MVPA) to study neural representation of others’ mental states (social cognition). Functional MRI study in adults manipulating social-interactive context (perceived live vs recorded speech) measuring neural processing of social communication/mentalizing; involves healthy participants and addresses social-related processing relevant to review objective.

Empirical fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants performing empathy-evoking (social cognition) tasks during scanning; investigates neural mechanisms of social/emotion processing. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Whole-brain fMRI was collected while healthy adult participants viewed and processed faces of other group members—an explicit social-perception/understanding task (tracking sociometric popularity). Fits the review objective (social processing in healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with an explicit social task (control of interpersonal trust/distrust) in healthy adult participants (n=60). Investigates neural correlates of social attitude regulation (perception/understanding of others), and is an original empirical study, not a review—meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating processing of social versus nonsocial gestures and social cognitive/affective processing. Abstract implies non-clinical participants and directly addresses social processing relevant to review objective. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and health status.

Hyperscanning fMRI study examining mutual gaze and joint attention — clearly social processing. fMRI study examining neural correlates of speech acts (social communication). Abstract reports task-based fMRI with participants and social-interaction processing; likely healthy adults. Age/sample details not given in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI study investigating agency and communion (core social cognition constructs) using a task-based design—meets review objective. fMRI study examining disgust perception in racial prejudice addresses social cognition (perception of others) and used a social-related task. fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (a social processing paradigm) in human participants examining neural correlates of romantic relationship satisfaction. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text confirmation.

Human fMRI experiment examining self-referential and social stimulus processing (social-related task). Reports neural activations for social processing; meets inclusion criteria. Primary research using fMRI while participants read literary passages varying in social vs non-social content; probes social-cognitive/theory-of-mind processes and reports dmPFC activity. Original fMRI experiment in which healthy participants viewed social interactions (violent conflict) with attention to aggressor vs. victim — a social perception/understanding task relevant to the review. The study used fMRI during an empathy-for-pain task manipulating ingroup/outgroup (minimal group paradigm), which is a social-related process (perception/understanding of others). Abstract describes fMRI of negative emotion processing and sex differences in fronto-limbic connectivity in adults but does not specify whether the task is social-related. Abstract addresses Theory of Mind and mPFC (relevant social processing) but does not state whether an fMRI was conducted during a social task or participant characteristics (healthy adults). Insufficient methodological detail in abstract — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study where participants performed a gaze-following task involving in-group/out-group political figures—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others/social attention). fMRI paradigm (EmpaToM) administered to healthy adult samples (N=90, N=178) probing social cognition (empathy and Theory of Mind). fMRI study in healthy adult male and female participants examining neural processing of social reputation (a social-related task). Fits inclusion criteria (social processing, functional MRI, healthy adults aged likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports functional neuroimaging (fMRI) while participants viewed social scenes, a social-cognition/mentalizing task linked to perception/understanding of others. fMRI study in healthy participants examining spontaneous imitation—an aspect of social cognition (perception/understanding of others, social communication). Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI in healthy adults); not a review.

fMRI study in 164 healthy adults performing an interactive mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) task assessing attachment/affiliation-related processing. Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study examining mental-state reasoning vs action representation (why/how questions), which pertains to social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Original fMRI study measuring STS responses to a range of social and linguistic stimuli in human participants, addressing social perception and cognition. Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in humans.

Primary fMRI study investigating social gaze processing (perception/understanding of others). Uses an fMRI social task in human participants and reports behavioral and neural results. Abstract reports an empirical fMRI study examining social working memory and social cognitive processing in humans (medial/lateral frontoparietal systems). fMRI study in young healthy adults performing an incentive delay task with social reward; directly investigates neural correlates of social reward processing. Meets inclusion criteria (task involving social processing, healthy participants aged within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study using an automatic imitation task with social-affective facial stimuli examining affiliation-related mimicry and neural processes. Functional MRI study examining social (vs nonsocial) attributions and associated brain regions (DMPFC) in human participants. Abstract describes social cognitive processing relevant to the review. fMRI study with 18 human participants performing a social cognition task (predicting others' behavior; ToM and deontic inference). fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=37) performing a social communication task (feeling addressed); examines neural processing of social cues (gestures, body orientation). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural dynamics of social tie formation during a public good game — a social interaction task probing prosocial behavior. Abstract indicates human fMRI data and social processing. Participant health/age not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining processing of mutual vs. averted gaze—clearly a social-perception/understanding-of-others task in humans.
