Participant ages/health not specified in abstract, so full text is needed to confirm age range/health status.

fMRI study in healthy 'normal subjects' who watched realistic social-interaction movie clips—task explicitly involves social perception/processing (interaction vs single person). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI in healthy adults); not a review.

fMRI study of social processing (judgments of fairness/cooperation) in human participants; reports neural responses to moral/social status of faces. Likely healthy adult sample; abstract meets inclusion for social-related fMRI. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health.

Event-related fMRI study where human subjects viewed faces and made trustworthiness judgments—clearly a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). Conducted in human subjects (healthy adults implied); not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction and age confirmation.

Functional MRI study examining social cognition (empathy and forgiveness) with healthy volunteers (n=10). Participants performed social-related tasks (judging others' emotional states and forgivability), directly matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Ages not specified in abstract but described as volunteers; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (White and Black subjects) measuring amygdala responses to ingroup vs outgroup faces — a social perception/understanding of others task. Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social interaction discrimination task (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy adult group aged 20–41, within the 17–65 range. This is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=30) performing social-emotional face tasks (gender identification of angry and happy faces), which assesses perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 25 healthy adult participants presenting faces vs scrambled images; investigates facial color processing relevant to social communication/perception of others. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review.

fMRI study examining anticipatory interpersonal touch (human vs inanimate hand), addressing social-sensorimotor processing relevant to social cognition. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages/health status explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and eligibility.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self/other evaluations). It includes a healthy adult group aged 22–31 (within 17–65). It is empirical primary research (not a review). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants investigating brain responses to interpersonal manual touch (social touch). This is social-related processing (affiliation/ social interaction), meets inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract describes a social decision-making task (ultimatum game) with reported neural activations, implying functional imaging of social processes. However participant ages and explicit use of fMRI are not specified and developmental focus raises uncertainty about adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm adult (17–65) healthy participants and fMRI methods.

Abstract reports participants judged ambiguous social interactions after tactile stimulation and describes neural activations (primary/secondary somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, inferior PFC), indicating fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; not a review. Sufficient information in abstract supports inclusion.

fMRI study using face vs object viewing (social perception of others) with a continuous sample including adults through adulthood; includes healthy adult participants; not a review. Meets criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study using a social-related task (perception of biological motion) with healthy adult participants (adults vs youth). Task probes social perception; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study examining perception of others’ gender from faces (face gender classification), a social-perception task relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others.’ Uses fMRI in human participants; likely healthy adult sample. Abstract does not suggest exclusion criteria (not a review). Include for full-text review.

Study used BOLD fMRI while participants made social-related judgments (affiliation vs isolation) in healthy human participants (younger and older adults). Not a review. Abstract lacks specific age ranges, so include for full-text verification of participant ages.

fMRI study in humans examining social communication (communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations) and STS responses; addresses social communication in likely healthy adult participants (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study includes a healthy adult group (ages 25–35). The task involves affective touch, which is relevant to social-affective processing (affiliation/attachment, social perception), but the abstract does not explicitly state a social task — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a self-vs-friend face recognition task (perception/understanding of self), a social-related construct. It appears to involve healthy adult participants, but demographics not specified in abstract — include for full-text verification of age/health criteria.

fMRI study examining face identity and eye-gaze perception (a social-communication process). Abstract confirms task-based fMRI targeting social-related processing. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of gaze/face processing, which is a social perception/communication task in humans. Authors report neural responses and connectivity; not a review. Although participant ages not stated in abstract, it clearly fits the review objective and likely involves healthy adult participants, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was acquired during a linked social interaction (a deception game) in human participants, meeting the review’s focus on social processing during fMRI. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion requires full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Functional MRI study using attributional decision tasks probing self-responsibility and the self-serving bias—core social-cognitive processes (perception/understanding of self/others). Abstract refers to 'normal subjects' (healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI in healthy right-handed adult subjects examined self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Study involves a healthy participant group aged likely within adult range and is an original fMRI experiment (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for the review.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants performing explicit and implicit facial emotion recognition — a social perception/communication task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study in healthy adults examining neural responses to images of own vs others' body parts (self- and other-perception). Task targets social-related processes (Perception and Understanding of Self/Others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Functional MRI was used to measure neural responses to observed actions (action observation/mirror system), a form of social processing (perception and understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adult volunteers. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in human participants performing self-judgment tasks (Perception/Understanding of Self), a social-related construct. Participants appear to be healthy adults across cultures; study is empirical (not a review). Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was performed during an explicit emotion-recognition task (social processing) in a group of healthy young adult males (within 17–65). The study is original research (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigates audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional signals (social communication) in humans and reports neural correlates; meets review topic. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).

Functional MRI study examining direct and reflected self-appraisals (a social-related task: Perception and Understanding of Self). Includes a healthy adult participant group aged 23–30, within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract investigates neural bases of perception and production of prosody (a social communication function). Title and content indicate neuroimaging of premotor regions in healthy participants and correlations with empathy/prosodic ability, fitting the review’s fMRI social-processing criterion. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages and imaging details.

fMRI study investigating social expectancy violations (perception/understanding of others: warmth and competence) in human perceivers; not a review. Although ages not specified, design clearly uses healthy participants in a social task, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social-related task (recognizing emotions and integrating gaze cues). The study includes a healthy younger adult group aged 17–27 (within 17–65). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

This is a machine learning methods paper on probabilistic graphical modeling for multi-view bipartite graph clustering; no fMRI or human social-task data are reported, and no healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks are involved.

This is an original fMRI study of identity discrimination of faces (individuation), which falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ — a social-related construct. Participants are described as human subjects (no clinical groups reported). Study is not a review/meta-analysis. Insufficient age detail, but likely healthy adults; inclusion appropriate for full-text review.

Task-based fMRI study of social processing (empathy/sympathy) in healthy participants. Sample age range 7–40 includes adults within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social task in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

Uses fMRI during a social task (Cyberball social rejection) in healthy participants and includes an adult female group (adults vs. adolescents). Meets social processing and healthy adult participant criteria; not a review.

fMRI study presenting dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset) — a social communication/perception task involving emotion processing. Appears to involve healthy adult participants; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining self-, mother-, and abstract-other (theory of mind) processing—clearly social-related tasks with neural measures. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) group.

The abstract states this is a literature review (reviews influence of hallucinogens/entactogens) and does not report original fMRI experiments in human participants. It therefore does not meet the inclusion requirement for primary fMRI studies and is not eligible.

Study used fMRI while participants recalled museum displays about World War II, probing medial prefrontal cortex involvement in collective memory and social cognition. This is a social-related processing task in (presumably) healthy adult participants and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

Resting-state fMRI in a sample of ASD toddlers (not task-based) and focuses on early childhood; no healthy adult (age 17–65) task-based social processing group is reported. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural processing of social touch (social communication/perception). Although focused on ASD, such studies typically include a healthy control group; abstract does not explicitly state controls or ages. Insufficient detail to confirm controls, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using voice stimuli demonstrating voice-sensitive auditory cortex and infraslow BOLD oscillations; voice processing is social communication/perception relevant. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets criteria.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=31) observed goal-directed hand actions, addressing perception/understanding of others — a social-related construct. Includes a healthy adult group and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study investigating neural representations of honesty and their influence on trust behavior — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI data were resting-state functional connectivity, not a task-based social processing fMRI. Although healthy controls were included, no fMRI social-related task was performed; social cognition was measured behaviorally. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task-based social fMRI.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of facial expression processing (a social task), matching the review objective. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

All participants are adolescents (age 16–17); the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract does not indicate adult participants, so the study falls outside the eligible age range.

fMRI was conducted while participants (15 patients, 15 healthy controls) played a social task (prisoner’s dilemma), directly probing social behaviour and neural correlates. Includes a healthy adult control group; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; full-text review recommended.

This paper is a meta-analytic review (combining PubMed search, Neurosynth, and resting-state analyses) rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Although it addresses social cognition among other domains, it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study using an interactive trust game (social reward/ToM) and includes a healthy control group. Controls are aged 13–19; exact number of participants ≥17 is not reported. Age eligibility unclear from abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy participants fall within 17–65.

This study investigates visual gamma activity during a color discrimination task (visual/perceptual processing), not social-related processing. It does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI task involving social constructs.

Study used rtfMRI neurofeedback for emotion regulation of the hippocampus in healthy volunteers; it does not report an fMRI task probing social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Therefore it does not meet the requirement of a social-related task during scanning.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task). Meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults. Although healthy controls are included, no social task was performed, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study of rTMS effects on mFP–amygdala connectivity in healthy adults; no task-based social processing was performed. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

This is a narrative review/theoretical paper summarizing human neuroimaging literature on the cerebellum, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It does not report task-based fMRI data; it is a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses or reviews.

fMRI study with 36 healthy participants performing vocal emotional processing (perception of emotional speech), which fits social-related processing (social communication/perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult participants and task content justify inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study (N=31) of healthy adults viewing disfigured faces; assesses social perception/empathy and neural responses (ventral occipito-temporal, ACC). Task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others), meeting inclusion criteria; not a review.

Primary fMRI study investigating neural processing of social interactions (perception/understanding of others) using multivoxel pattern analysis. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study in a healthy adult sample (n=51) measuring processing of dynamic facial expressions — a social communication/perception task. No indication of psychiatric/neurological participants and the paper is original research (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI database including tasks for social perception and reasoning in a sample of 78 participants. Although participant ages/health status are not explicitly stated, the study clearly involves social-related processing; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult ages and task details.

Primary fMRI study examining neural responses to social exclusion (a social-related task) in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=71 females). Targets social processing (ostracism/affiliation) and is not a review, meeting the review inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although it uses fMRI on a social task, the sample does not meet the age criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although it addresses social processing (face memory), it does not meet the criterion requiring task-based social fMRI, so exclude.

This article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies, not an original fMRI study with human participants. The review’s exclusion criteria remove systematic reviews and meta-analyses, so it should be excluded.

Human fMRI study measuring BOLD responses to perceived animacy from visual motion cues—a form of social perception (perception/understanding of others). Involves neuroimaging in healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets the inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social-inclusion task (social processing). Includes a healthy control group (n=17) alongside clinical groups, and is empirical primary research (not a review). Although ages are not specified in the abstract, the participant descriptions (diagnosed clinical groups and controls) strongly imply adult samples. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) to examine amygdala network causality across the lifespan. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing in adults 17–65. Although it examines social networks and involves healthy participants, the absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining socioemotional processing (empathy/anxiety), which fits social-related constructs (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so insufficient info to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants examining co-speech gestures and their effect on semantic processing — a form of social communication. Fits the ‘Social Communication’ construct; meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria evident from the abstract.

Empathy-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=26) performing a social-cognitive task (observing human and robot pain/pleasure). Fits review objective of social processing fMRI in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of live reciprocal social interaction comparing human-human and human-robot interactions in a sample of 21 participants; assesses social cognition (mentalizing, social motivation). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults within 17–65.

fMRI study investigating face perception and recognition (Perception/Understanding of Others) in healthy human participants. Fits inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met. Full text can confirm ages.

Study used fMRI during a live social task (mutual eye contact) in healthy adult participants (16 pairs), addressing social perception/interaction and reporting task-related activations and connectivity. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Study analyzes intrinsic structure–function coupling using multimodal MRI in ASD and controls, not task-based fMRI of social processing. No social-related task or task-evoked activations in healthy adults are reported; thus does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study targeting pSTS using dynamic facial expressions — a social perception task (facial expression recognition). Abstract implies human subjects and task fits social processing. However participant health status and ages (17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
This is a rodent neuroimaging study (Fmr1 knockout mice) examining mGluR5 and connectivity; no human participants or social-processing task and thus does not include healthy adults aged 17–65.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy younger and older adults, meeting the review objective. Age ranges are not specified, so inclusion cannot be confirmed or excluded based on age; per instructions, include for full-text review to verify participant ages and other details.

fMRI was conducted while participants engaged in a social task (spontaneous conversation). The study includes a matched typically developing (healthy) control group of young adult males, satisfying the 17–65 healthy participant criterion and addressing social processing in fMRI.

Participants are early adolescents (aged 10.5–13.4), falling outside the 17–65 adult age range, and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based social processing fMRI paradigm. Therefore it does not meet the age or task-based inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using an interpersonal pleasant touch paradigm manipulating social context (male vs female), which is a social-related task. Includes a matched healthy control group of adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Dual-fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social exchange task examines interpersonal social cognition and brain responses—fits fMRI social-related task criterion. Although the abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, the study appears to involve healthy adult interactants; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

Study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult males performing a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm), assessing neural responses and social-cognitive processing. This fits the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study of trustworthiness appraisal (social processing) comparing BPD to controls; includes at least one healthy control group relevant to social processing. Abstract implies task-based fMRI examining social perception. Age range not specified in abstract, but inclusion warranted for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related task during fMRI; not a review. Information on exact ages not provided but 'healthy subjects' implies target population; include for full-text confirmation as needed.

The abstract describes a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (Neurosynth analyses, lesion work, TMS, MVPA) rather than reporting primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Resting-state (no social-related task) fMRI study; participants are adolescents (mean ~14.5, range 10–18) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Thus does not meet task-based and adult participant inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI and intraoperative cortical electrostimulation to map mentalizing networks rather than an fMRI task of social processing in healthy adults. No task-based social-related fMRI in healthy participants is reported in the abstract, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (double-blind crossover, n=20 males) performing an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma assessing cooperation/trust while scanned—directly examines social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis.

This is a narrative review discussing resting-state fMRI and interventions in ASD rather than an original task-based fMRI study. It does not report fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion for reviews. Therefore exclude.

This study is not an fMRI experiment and focuses on screening measures for autism in children using questionnaires (M-CHAT-R, BISQ). Participants are not healthy adults (age 17–65), and no social-related fMRI task is described. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social cognition (prediction of others’ mental states) using social-brain analyses. Participants described as male and female; task involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring brain activity during learning about others’ trustworthiness (social cognitive task: perception/understanding of others). Includes healthy younger and older adult groups; not a review. Age groups not fully specified but younger group likely within 17–65; sufficient to include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—falls under social perception/communication. fMRI study in adults using an emotional face recognition task of own child’s facial emotions (social processing: perception/understanding of others, attachment). Includes a healthy participant group (mothers without current mental disorders). Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria evident from abstract.

This paper is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract does not present primary fMRI data on healthy participants performing social tasks, so it should be excluded.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men viewing attachment-related (erotic) and fearful social scenes. This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and fear), participants are healthy adults within age range, and it is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract explicitly includes a social cognition task among the tasks analyzed, and uses task-based fMRI whole-brain connectivity. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm healthy adult sample and age range. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in young adults with high-functioning ASD and healthy controls; no task-based social processing was performed. Inclusion requires task fMRI of social-related processing, so the study does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

This is a review article of fNIRS studies in children/infants with ASD (not primary fMRI research). It reviews studies and focuses on clinical pediatric populations and a different imaging modality, thus not meeting inclusion criteria (fMRI in healthy adults) and meets exclusion (review).

This is not an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The abstract describes a review of ecstatic/epileptic phenomena and neuroimaging (clinical populations) and appears to be a review rather than an fMRI experiment with healthy participants performing social tasks.

The abstract states this is a literature review (reviews influence of hallucinogens/entactogens) and does not report original fMRI experiments in human participants. It therefore does not meet the inclusion requirement for primary fMRI studies and is not eligible.

Study used fMRI while participants recalled museum displays about World War II, probing medial prefrontal cortex involvement in collective memory and social cognition. fMRI study examining neural processing of social touch (social communication/perception). Although focused on ASD, such studies typically include a healthy control group; abstract does not explicitly state controls or ages. Insufficient detail to confirm controls, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=31) observed goal-directed hand actions, addressing perception/understanding of others — a social-related construct. Includes a healthy adult group and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

All participants in this fMRI study have alcohol use disorder (clinical sample); no healthy control group (age 17–65) is reported. Thus it does not include a healthy adult group required by the review.

Original fMRI study investigating neural representations of honesty and their influence on trust behavior — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI data were resting-state functional connectivity, not a task-based social processing fMRI. Although healthy controls were included, no fMRI social-related task was performed; social cognition was measured behaviorally. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task-based social fMRI.

Resting-state fMRI study of rTMS effects on mFP–amygdala connectivity in healthy adults; no task-based social processing was performed. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

Age ranges are not specified, so inclusion cannot be confirmed or excluded based on age; per instructions, include for full-text review to verify participant ages and other details.

Participants are early adolescents (aged 10.5–13.4), falling outside the 17–65 adult age range, and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based social processing fMRI paradigm. Therefore it does not meet the age or task-based inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using an interpersonal pleasant touch paradigm manipulating social context (male vs female), which is a social-related task. Includes a matched healthy control group of adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Dual-fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social exchange task examines interpersonal social cognition and brain responses—fits fMRI social-related task criterion. Although the abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, the study appears to involve healthy adult interactants; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

Study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult males performing a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm), assessing neural responses and social-cognitive processing. This fits the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related task during fMRI; not a review. Information on exact ages not provided but 'healthy subjects' implies target population; include for full-text confirmation as needed.

The abstract describes a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (Neurosynth analyses, lesion work, TMS, MVPA) rather than reporting primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Resting-state (no social-related task) fMRI study; participants are adolescents (mean ~14.5, range 10–18) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Thus does not meet task-based and adult participant inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI and intraoperative cortical electrostimulation to map mentalizing networks rather than an fMRI task of social processing in healthy adults. No task-based social-related fMRI in healthy participants is reported in the abstract, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study participants are children (NVLD, ASD, and typically developing children); the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Abstract does not report adult participants, so it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social cognition (prediction of others’ mental states) using social-brain analyses. Participants described as male and female; task involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring brain activity during learning about others’ trustworthiness (social cognitive task: perception/understanding of others). Includes healthy younger and older adult groups; not a review. Age groups not fully specified but younger group likely within 17–65; sufficient to include for full-text review.

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis of social cognition in PTSD (systematic review/meta-analysis). It does not report original fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks. This meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The abstract indicates this is a review of task-based EEG and fMRI studies (a review article), not an original fMRI study. It focuses on 22q11.2 deletion syndrome carriers rather than reporting fMRI data from healthy adults. Meets exclusion (systematic review) and does not clearly meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with a social-related task (recall of relationship episodes) in 35 healthy individuals; not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages, so include for full-text screening to confirm age criteria (17–65).

fMRI study in adults using an emotional face recognition task of own child’s facial emotions (social processing: perception/understanding of others, attachment). Includes a healthy participant group (mothers without current mental disorders). Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria evident from abstract.

This paper is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract does not present primary fMRI data on healthy participants performing social tasks, so it should be excluded.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men viewing attachment-related (erotic) and fearful social scenes. This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and fear), participants are healthy adults within age range, and it is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract explicitly includes a social cognition task among the tasks analyzed, and uses task-based fMRI whole-brain connectivity. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm healthy adult sample and age range. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is not an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The abstract describes a review of ecstatic/epileptic phenomena and neuroimaging (clinical populations) and appears to be a review rather than an fMRI experiment with healthy participants performing social tasks.

This is a review article about neural origins of face areas in human and macaque infants, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It focuses on infant data and is a review, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and failing the adult participant requirement.

Study used non-human primates (macaque monkeys) rather than human participants. Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy humans (age 17–65). Although relevant topic and uses fMRI, participant species does not meet the inclusion criterion.

This is a narrative review (Annual Review of Neuroscience) discussing neural mechanisms across primates, not an original fMRI study in healthy adult humans performing a social task. Excluded per criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses (no primary fMRI data reported).

fMRI was used to measure neural responses while healthy human participants performed a social communication task (discriminating emotional valence of vocalisations). The study examines perception/understanding of others and reports STS responses, meeting inclusion criteria. Age range not specified but participants are adults; include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in prairie voles (non-human animals) under anesthesia; no human participants and no task-based social processing. Does not meet requirement of fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.
The study used macaque monkeys (non-human primates) rather than human participants. The review requires fMRI studies in healthy adult humans (age 17–65), so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Non-human animal study (rats) using resting-state fMRI under light anesthesia, not a task-based fMRI of social processing in humans. Participants are not healthy adult humans (17–65), and the study does not investigate social-related task performance. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Study was conducted in non-human primates (monkeys), not healthy human adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring human participants.
Participants are non-human (dogs). Inclusion requires fMRI studies with human participants (age 17–65). The abstract clearly reports canine subjects, so it does not meet the population criterion.

This is a conceptual/essay arguing for cross-species social neuroscience, not an empirical fMRI study in human participants; no methods, no fMRI data, and no participant group described. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are domestic dogs (non-human). The review requires fMRI studies of healthy human adults (age 17–65); this study does not include human participants, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Study used macaque monkeys (non-human subjects). The review requires fMRI studies with healthy human participants aged 17–65, so this does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

Non-human study (macaque monkeys) using resting-state fMRI; no human participants aged 17–65 and no task-based social processing. Does not meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social-task studies in healthy adults.

Animal (mouse) rs-fcMRI study; no human participants or social task; does not include healthy adult human subjects performing social-related processing. Exclude based on population and outcome mismatch.
Participants are non-human (domestic dogs); the meta-analysis requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). This study does not meet the population criterion.
Participants were non-human (dogs, N=12). The review requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). Study does not meet participant inclusion criteria.

Study used rhesus monkeys with single-unit recordings and LFPs in an fMRI-defined area; no human participants (age 17–65) and not an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study investigates birdsong and references fMRI in songbirds; it does not involve human participants or fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study includes human participants processing emotional facial expressions — a social communication task related to perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state ages explicitly, so include for full-text confirmation of participant ages and health status.

This is a comparative/narrative review of face perception across species, focusing on behavioral experiments and evolutionary discussion. It does not report original fMRI data collected in healthy adult humans performing social-related tasks, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.
Study used macaque monkeys (non-human) rather than human participants; inclusion requires fMRI in healthy human adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the population criterion.

This article is a review (not an original fMRI study). Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses. The abstract does not report primary fMRI data of social processing in healthy adults, so exclude based on abstract.

The study used EEG (mu rhythm) rather than functional MRI. Although it examines social processing (emotion recognition from faces) in healthy adults, the meta-analysis objective is limited to fMRI studies; therefore this study does not meet the imaging modality inclusion criterion.

This is a methodological/narrative review of hyperscanning techniques (EEG/fMRI) discussing advantages and future directions, not an original fMRI study reporting data from healthy adults performing a social-related task. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reads like a narrative overview and does not report specific fMRI methods, participant numbers, or confirm healthy adult samples. It mentions early fMRI studies but provides insufficient detail to determine if this paper presents original task-based fMRI data in healthy adults. Include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Single-case neuroimaging study of an 8-year-old with massive bilateral frontal damage (a pediatric patient), not a group of healthy adults (age 17–65). Although fMRI was performed, it does not assess social processing in healthy adult participants.

This is a book chapter/review focused on adolescent development and developmental neuroscience, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It does not report fMRI data from participants aged 17–65 and appears to be a review rather than primary research.

Abstract focuses on fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing in 4- and 6-year-old children and mentions comparisons to adults, but does not clearly state adult age range or whether the task targets social processing. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65 and a social-related task). Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Participants are children in middle childhood (ages 8–12). Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; no adult group is reported. Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the age range excludes it.

Task-based fMRI examining social exclusion and mentalizing in human participants (social processing). Participants described as healthy male adolescents, but exact ages not provided to confirm they fall within 17–65. Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and health status.

Participants are described as adolescent girls (recruited from reports from 2nd–8th grades), i.e., under age 17, so the study population falls outside the required adult age range (17–65). Although an fMRI risk-taking task was used, the sample age criterion is not met.

fMRI task examining social inclusion/exclusion in a population-derived sample; appears to involve healthy participants and social processing. Abstract specifies adolescents but does not give ages, so eligibility regarding the 17–65 age range cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to determine participant ages and confirm inclusion criteria.

Abstract explicitly states this is a review article. It does not report original fMRI data from human participants performing social tasks in healthy adults, so it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.
Participants are children in middle childhood (approximately ages 7–13), not adults. Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Age criterion clearly not met based on the abstract.

fMRI study of social processing (peer influence via 'likes') in human participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages beyond 'adolescents,' so eligibility (≥17) is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
Participants were children (mean age 10.2 years), outside the required adult age range (17–65). Although fMRI assessed social communication, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Abstract describes adolescent response inhibition and gene–environment interaction in context of ADHD; it does not mention use of fMRI or a social-related task, and participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Not a systematic review.
Participants were preadolescents (scanned at age 11), outside the required adult age range (17–65) for inclusion. The study does use fMRI and a social task, but the age criterion excludes it.

Task-state fMRI examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of self) and includes a healthy control group. The abstract does not report ages of controls (inclusion requires ages 17–65), so full-text review is needed to confirm age and task details; therefore include for full-text screening.

The study reports fMRI in children and adolescents (developmental sample) with no adult group in the 17–65 age range. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.

This is a narrative review of social skill development in children, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report fMRI data on adults.

Participants were children aged 8–12, which does not meet the inclusion age range of 17–65 for healthy adult samples. Although the study used fMRI and a social task, the sample age clearly excludes it.
Participants are infants aged 4–7 months, not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review. The study population does not meet the age/group inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of neural responses to parent stimuli assessing social cognition/mentalizing (social-related task). Participants are human adolescents with mean age 17 (within 17–65 inclusion range) and appear to be a healthy sample. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

All participants are older adults (mean age 79), which falls outside the required 17–65 age range; abstract provides no evidence of a healthy participant group within 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.
Participants are children (ages 3–5), not adults 17–65; study uses resting-state fMRI assessing intrinsic connectivity rather than an fMRI social task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants were adolescents aged 12–15 with no adult (17–65) healthy group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65, so the study does not meet the age criterion.

Participants were 63 adolescents (no adult group). Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65; the abstract provides no evidence of participants within that age range. Although an fMRI social-related task was used, the sample age does not meet criteria.

fMRI study measuring maternal neural responses to infant cry (attachment-related social processing) in healthy adult mothers. Task is social-related (affiliation/attachment). Participants are human adults; no indication of clinical populations. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study used fMRI to examine memory processes (working memory and incidental episodic encoding), not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of self/others). Participants are healthy adults but the task is non-social, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Participants are described as adolescents aged 14–18 (typically developing). The meta-analysis requires healthy participants aged 17–65; the sample is primarily underage and does not meet the adult age criterion based on the abstract.
Participants are children and adolescents aged 8–17; no adult (17–65) healthy participant group is reported, so does not meet the review’s adult age criterion.

Functional MRI study of social evaluation/impression formation conducted in human participants; includes a healthy young adult group (n=15) likely within 17–65; directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient abstract information to meet inclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review/perspective on adolescent social brain development, not an original task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (17–65). The abstract summarizes existing structural and fMRI findings in adolescence and offers speculation; no original methods/results from adult participants performing social tasks are reported, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Not an fMRI study: methods are focus group and questionnaire (qualitative) with adolescent students. No functional MRI scanning during social tasks and participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants were 11–16-year-old boys (adolescents), not adults aged 17–65 as required by the review’s inclusion criteria; therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for healthy adult participants.

Participants are described as early adolescents (study of adolescent development and sex differences); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is reported. Fails the age inclusion criterion despite using fMRI social tasks.
Study used fMRI in 3–7-month-old infants; the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. No adult participant group is present, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Study focuses on development in early adolescence (longitudinal adolescent sample) rather than healthy adults; no indication of a participant group aged 17–65. Thus does not meet the inclusion age criterion for adult fMRI studies.

Abstract reports an fMRI social task (Trust Game) in adolescents but does not specify participant ages; inclusion requires at least one healthy group aged 17–65. Because age eligibility is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to verify age range and eligibility.

This article is a narrative review integrating fMRI and behavioural studies of adolescent social cognition, not an original fMRI study with participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides no new primary fMRI data on healthy adults aged 17–65.

fMRI was used while participants viewed stigmatized and control faces (a social cognition task - perception/understanding of others). The study includes healthy young adults (presumably within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Participants were adolescents aged 9–17 (group spanning minors); no distinct group of healthy adults within the required 17–65 age range is reported. Although fMRI social task was used, the sample does not meet the adult age criterion.

Participants were children and adolescents aged 10–17 (no adult sample within the required 17–65 range). Although fMRI and social/moral tasks were used, the age criterion for healthy adults is not met.
Participants are children aged 7–12, not adults 17–65 required by the review. Although it is an fMRI study of social processing, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Participants are children (mean age 10.1 years), which falls well below the required adult age range (17–65). Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample does not meet the review’s age inclusion criteria.

Participants were children (7–10 years); the review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65. The abstract reports only child participants, so it does not meet the age-related inclusion criterion.

The article is a narrative review of MRI findings in adolescence, not an original fMRI study. It does not report fMRI experiments in healthy adults (17–65). It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks requisite participant/sample details for inclusion.

The study uses fMRI in preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks PMA) and investigates somatosensory/motor somatotopic mapping, not social-related processing; participants are infants, not healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

All participants are adolescents (adolescent boys); the healthy control group is not within the required age range (17–65). Therefore the study does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion for healthy adults.

fMRI study of social-evaluation (viewing camera cues) measuring neural responses related to self-conscious emotion—clearly a social-processing task. Includes child, adolescent, and adult participants; adult group age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm adults fall within 17–65.

fMRI study in healthy adults (participants aged 24) involving social regulation during friend/stranger handholding — a social-related task (affiliation/attachment). Meets age and task criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social influence (expert advice) on decision-making, addressing social cognition processes. Includes an adult group (18+), meeting the 17–65 age criterion; participants appear healthy (no clinical populations reported). Directly relevant to social-related processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

Study used fMRI in 22 healthy adult (male) participants performing social-related tasks (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgments). Participants are within the adult age range; task assesses social cognition constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study of person perception/social expectations (social processing). Involves healthy adult participants (political targets) and reports neural results; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=22) investigating perception of CT-targeted affective (social) touch, a social-processing task involving affiliation/social interaction; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study (N=61 healthy adult White participants) performing a social impression-formation task of faces varying by race and socioeconomic status, examining neural responses (NAcc, VMPFC, amygdala). It investigates social perception/processing and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining perception and integration of faces and voices—a social perception/communication task—performed in human participants (n=20). Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit statement of clinical populations or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult participants and age range.

fMRI study investigating empathy (perception/understanding of others), reporting neural activation during a social-related task in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages aren’t specified, the study clearly fits the review’s focus and likely used healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

Study 2 reports fMRI activation while participants viewed sexualized and clothed human targets, addressing mental state attribution (a social cognition task) in healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Study used event-related fMRI (with EEG) while healthy adult participants (mean age 29) viewed and perceived others' emotional facial expressions—directly addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others/empathy). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=18, ages ~40), performing an ecologically valid joint-action social task (leading vs following) relevant to social processing (perception/understanding of others, social cognition/communication). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain univariate contrasts (e.g., Leading>Rest, Following>Rest, Leading>Following) with random-effects analyses and cluster-corrected voxelwise results; Talairach coordinates and figures/tables of activations are reported. Results are clearly from the healthy control sample and generalize to healthy adults. The study is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and does not fall under exclusion criteria. Although some exploratory regressions used a lenient threshold and authors note limitations (small N, potential gender confound), primary whole-brain task-evoked maps are reported. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Although this is an fMRI study of social impression formation in healthy adult participants (N=60, mean age 23.8), the manuscript reports multivariate behavioral PLS analyses and brain–behavior correlation (BSR) maps rather than group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (e.g., main-effect or within-group voxelwise contrasts). The paper references prior/unpublished univariate analyses of the same dataset but does not present an unmasked, group-level voxelwise activation map for the healthy sample within this manuscript. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain task activation map for the healthy/control group, this study fails that criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults (n=16, ages 22–34). Participants watched a 20-min movie and social interactions were coded; analyses used a GLM with group-level, whole-brain second-level F-tests and post hoc t-tests. Results include voxelwise, univariate whole-brain statistical maps (voxelwise FWE p<0.05 with clusterwise correction) and reported peak coordinates/tables, clearly from the healthy adult group. The task probes perception and interpretation of others’ social interactions (social cognition/communication). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing using a task contrasting social vs nonsocial positive and negative scenes (approach–avoidance), meeting the review’s construct (affiliation/social perception). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (final N=76, males, mean age ~21) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level univariate task contrasts and second-level analyses; although many a priori ROI/SVC analyses are reported, the Methods state and Results reference additional whole-brain exploratory analyses (thresholds and reporting of clusters), indicating availability of whole-brain task-evoked group maps (reported in main text/supplement). Therefore it meets the requirement for whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mind perception/gaze-cueing) in healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age 24.4). The authors report whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric regressors for mind ratings and gaze-cueing effects) with cluster-based correction and present statistically thresholded activation maps and tables (e.g., vmPFC, TPJ, fusiform). All inclusion criteria are satisfied (social-related fMRI task; healthy adults within 17–65; group-level whole-brain univariate results). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (empathic accuracy/understanding of others) in healthy adults (final N=34, ages 20–30). The task is a social-related, naturalistic Empathic Accuracy Task. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate analyses (emotional > neutral contrasts, parametric modulators, time-series correlations) using SPM12 and nonparametric permutation testing with TFCE FWE correction; results are presented as whole-brain clusters/tables and figures. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and healthy-group results are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (ages 18–28) and reports voxelwise activation coordinates, the authors explicitly restricted their voxelwise search regions to predefined ROIs (amygdala, insula, IFG, ACC, thalamus, caudate, mOFC) rather than reporting an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map. The inclusion criteria require at least one group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked map generalizable to healthy adults. Because all reported statistical inferences were ROI-restricted (no whole-brain results reported), the study fails the whole-brain evidence requirement and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study on social communication: participants classified speakers’ communicative intentions from prosody (social communicative processing). Sample: 22 healthy adult native German participants (mean age 27.4), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction; activations are described in the text and figures. Although PPI connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain task activation maps from the healthy adult group are present and clearly generalized to the healthy population. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not between-group-only, not non-empirical). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm in which participants allocate money to another person under free vs controlled conditions (a social control-aversion task). Sample: 51 healthy adult participants (mean age 22, within 17–65), with exclusions noted and analyses reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak coordinates, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Although the study also includes connectivity (PPI) analyses, it additionally provides univariate, group-level whole-brain activation maps for the healthy sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met: social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results reported.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=25 in Study 1; ages 19–24; Study 2 behavioral n=33 also healthy). The task investigates social-related processing (emotion perception/social communication via facial expressions and vocal prosody). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (3×3 repeated-measures ANOVA and contrasts; PFWE-corrected results, cluster extents, and tables of activated regions/coordinates are provided) and ROI analyses. Results for the healthy adult group are clearly presented and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor patient-only samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=14 analyzed; ages 23–50). The task manipulates socialness (social vs. non-social images) and reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (social > nonsocial contrast) with voxelwise thresholds and FDR-corrected cluster inference; coordinates/clusters and conjunction maps are described. Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy adult group are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI, only connectivity, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI task study of social interaction perception in healthy adult participants (ages 18–34 and 18–30 across experiments). It reports group-level univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., social interaction > independent actions) with FDR-corrected results and surface-based group analyses, clearly from the healthy/control sample. The task probes perception/understanding of others (social interactions), not solely ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=37 male adults, mean age 22.9, within 17–65). The task is explicitly social-related (self-, friend-, celebrity- judgments) addressing Perception/Understanding of Self and Others. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (self vs. celebrity; friend vs. celebrity) with corrected thresholds (p<.05 FDR; voxelwise p<.001) and provides peak coordinates and cluster sizes, satisfying the whole-brain univariate result requirement. Analyses for task-evoked activity and gPPI connectivity are reported for the healthy sample and the whole-brain activation maps are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, not clinical-only, and participants are within age range). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI activation for social cognition (TOM vs Random) in a large sample of healthy adults (Human Connectome Project, n=787; ages 22–>35). The paper provides group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (Cohen's d and level-3 z maps) and describes cerebellar and whole-brain activation clusters for the social contrast. Healthy-control results are reported clearly and are generalizable to the healthy adult population. Although resting-state and seed-based analyses are also included, the paper contains the required task activation whole-brain maps (not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor between-group-only contrasts). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria for the review.

The study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 21–46) who viewed erotic pictures and videos depicting individuals and same-sex couples, engaging perception of others/social stimuli relevant to social processing constructs (Perception/Understanding of Others). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (one-sample within-group contrasts, FWE-corrected cluster maps) for each healthy orientation group, not limited to ROI analyses. Whole-brain results are clearly described and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or age outside range) are violated. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI task of social interaction (joint action, leading/following, haptic contact) in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age 40.4). It presents group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrasts (e.g., partnered vs non-partnered; improvisation contrasts) with statistical maps and Talairach coordinates, and corrections (FDR) reported. The task probes social-cognitive constructs (perception/understanding of others, mentalizing, social reward), satisfying the review’s content domain. It is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and the healthy adult group results are reported and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=36, ages ~20–25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task effects and parametric contrasts (cooperativity vs affectivity) with cluster-corrected statistical maps and tables of coordinates. Although DCM connectivity analyses are included, the study also provides the required healthy-group whole-brain task activation results (figures/tables) generalizable to healthy adults. Sample age is within 17–65 and results for healthy participants are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social/communicative paradigm (collaborative referential communication vs individual/arbitrary learning), directly addressing social communication and mentalizing. Sample: healthy adult participants (directors and matchers; age range 18–33), meeting the 17–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Collaborative > Individual, Collaborative > Arbitrary, Individual > Arbitrary) with cluster-corrected results presented in tables and figures and described in the text; these are generalizable healthy-group task effects. Although an ROI hippocampal analysis is also reported, whole-brain analyses are primary and satisfy inclusion. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adults reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=59 across three unique participant samples) performing social-related tasks (person knowledge, famous faces/names, socially relevant concept words). Group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with thresholding and peak MNI coordinates and whole-brain maps described in the text and tables. The sample is healthy adults and results for the healthy groups are reported separately. The study is empirical and not ROI-only, and does not rely solely on connectivity/resting-state or between-group-only contrasts. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI in a healthy adult sample (N=20; ages 23–38) using a social decision-making paradigm (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing Theory-of-Mind/social cognition. The paper provides group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise results (conjunction of task>control and contrasts such as COMP>COOP) with cluster correction and tables of MNI coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study also includes connectivity analyses, but crucially it includes unmasked whole-brain task activation maps, not ROI-only or resting-state-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adults and examines social/attachment processing, all reported neuroimaging results are seed-based resting‑state functional connectivity (post‑narrative carry‑over effects) rather than group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) activation maps. The paper does not present an unmasked whole-brain task activation map for the healthy group (only FC contrasts and seed-based connectivity results). Per the review’s inclusion criteria, studies must report at least one whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise result for the healthy/control group; therefore this study must be excluded.

Although the study is an fMRI investigation of social evaluation in a healthy adult sample (ages within 17–65) and uses an appropriate social task, the reported neuroimaging results are limited to small-volume–corrected ROI analyses in the ventral ACC. The paper describes group-level modeling and ROI-based SVC (bilateral vACC) and reports only vACC clusters from that ROI. I could not find any unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation maps or whole-brain voxelwise results reported for the healthy group. Because the inclusion criteria require at least one group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map generalizable to healthy adults, and the exclusion criteria disqualify studies that report only ROI analyses with no whole-brain results, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence requirement and should be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (body motion, social involvement) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task contrasts (main effects and interactions of stimulus type and movement direction) and provides stereotaxic coordinates of BOLD peaks and statistical details. Although targeted masks for the Mirror Neuron and Mentalizing systems were used for searching and inference, whole-brain contrasts were obtained at second level and results are reported as coordinate tables/peaks, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation maps in a healthy adult sample. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample) apply. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=30, females aged 19–39) to probe social cognition (kinship/moral dilemma) via an ecologically valid movie and a separate moral-dilemma decision task. It reports voxelwise, whole-brain analyses: (1) inter-subject correlation (ISC) results across the whole brain with FDR correction and cluster reporting, and (2) a group-level GLM contrast (decision vs. no-decision) with whole-brain cluster-corrected results (FDR/TFCE, permutation testing) and tables/figures of activations (VMPFC, ACC, DLPFC, etc.). This fulfills inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI during social-related processing, healthy adult sample, and reported group-level whole-brain univariate task activation maps. Not excluded by any criterion (not ROI-only, not resting-state only, no restricted age group). Thus include.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=14; ages 20–32). The study uses task-based fMRI with social-interaction stimuli and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrasts (e.g., interaction > independent; animate > physical), including peak MNI coordinates and statistical maps/figures. Although ROI analyses are also performed, whole-brain task-evoked univariate results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only; not resting-state or connectivity-only; participants are within 17–65). Therefore the paper meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=27, males aged 20–32) performing social/affiliation-related tasks (an Implicit Association Test with monogamy vs. adultery stimuli and a go/no-go task with attractive female faces). The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked results for the IAT (incongruent vs. congruent contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and tables of activated regions, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although the go/no-go analysis focused on a right VLPFC anatomical constraint/ROI, the IAT provides an unmasked whole-brain activation map from the healthy control group. All inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, and group-level whole-brain activations) are met; no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult men (ages 22–50) using task-based visual stimuli that probe social/affiliative processing (romantic images; also sexual and neutral). The authors report whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (whole-head FLAME random-effects, cluster correction) and present group-level contrasts and tables/figures for sexual>neutral (combined participants) and romantic>neutral (within groups and between monogamous vs non-monogamous). Results are reported as voxelwise whole-brain activations (thresholded maps, coordinate tables and figures), meeting the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task map. The sample falls within the 17–65 age range and the paper is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-empirical. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

While the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants and examines social cognition (theory of mind), it reports primarily ROI-based MVPA and individually-defined localizer contrasts (first-level Belief > Photo) rather than presenting a group-level, whole-brain univariate task activation map for the healthy sample. The methods describe defining ROIs from first-level contrasts and report multivariate classification results; I could not find a clear group-level, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map (main effect or within-group contrast) reported in the main text or described as coming from the healthy/control group. Because the review requires at least one group-level whole-brain univariate task map, the study does not meet that inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (implicit/explicit theory of mind) in healthy adults (final N=22, mean age 24.4). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results from an explicit general-belief localizer (false-belief vs false-photograph) thresholded at q(FDR)<0.05 and provides peak Talairach coordinates and figures.
